benchmark_details.name: MMAR (Multi-disciplinary Multi-modal Audio Reasoning)
benchmark_details.overview: MMAR is a new benchmark designed to evaluate the deep reasoning capabilities of Audio-Language Models (ALMs) across massive multi-disciplinary tasks, comprising 1,000 meticulously curated audio-question-answer triplets. It focuses on real-world audio scenarios, requiring multi-step reasoning beyond surface-level understanding.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective of MMAR is to provide a rigorous benchmark for evaluating audio deep reasoning capabilities in a variety of audio contexts.

data.source: Collected from real-world internet videos with iterative error corrections.
data.annotation: Manual annotation by expert annotators trained in audio processing.

methodology.calculation: Accuracy is calculated based on the number of correct predictions from the model compared to the ground truth.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better reasoning capabilities of the models in handling multi-step audio reasoning tasks.
methodology.baseline_results: The best-performing open-source model Qwen-2.5-Omni achieves an average accuracy below 60%.
methodology.validation: Validated through expert review and quality control processes.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: Data sources are publicly available videos, minimizing privacy concerns.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: The dataset will be released under a CC-BY-NC license for non-commercial use.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Consent procedures are not applicable as the data is collected from public sources.
